metaTitle: 3-Bed Bungalow €385,000 | Pilar de La Horadada Costa Blanca
metaDescription: Stylish 3-bedroom bungalow in Torre De La Horadada. €385,000. Perfect holiday home near Blue Flag beaches. Premium build, 40% less than island markets.
heroIntro: Discover your Mediterranean escape in Torre De La Horadada, a charming corner of Pilar de La Horadada where authentic Spanish coastal living meets modern comfort. This exceptional 3-bedroom bungalow offers the perfect foundation for your holiday home dream—a sunshine retreat where you can wake to endless possibilities of beach days, tapas evenings, and golden sunsets. At €385,000, this premium-specification property delivers remarkable value, priced 40% below comparable Spanish island markets, making it an astute choice for discerning buyers seeking a second home investment. The 78m² thoughtfully designed interior maximizes light and flow, while the 24m² plot provides the intimate outdoor space perfect for morning coffee or twilight relaxation. Located just 20 minutes from some of Costa Blanca's most pristine Blue Flag beaches, this bungalow positions you perfectly between serene coastal moments and the vibrant social fabric of an established international community. Whether you envision long summers hosting family and friends, quiet winter escapes from northern climates, or a rental investment generating €800 weekly returns, this property adapts to your lifestyle. Torre De La Horadada has quietly become a preferred destination for holiday home buyers who value authenticity over overcrowded resorts—where Mediterranean beauty remains unspoiled and genuinely welcoming.
areaSection: Pilar de La Horadada sits on Spain's southern Costa Blanca coastline, in the province of Alicante, characterised by dramatic limestone cliffs, hidden coves, and crystalline Mediterranean waters. The area enjoys over 300 days of annual sunshine, with mild winters (rarely dropping below 10°C) and warm, sun-soaked summers. This southeastern corner of Spain remains refreshingly underdeveloped compared to neighbouring tourist hotspots—development here has been thoughtful rather than sprawling. The town itself retains genuine Spanish character: narrow streets wind past family-run restaurants, the weekly market brings fresh produce and local colour, and the pace of life encourages lingering conversations over cortados. Located just 40 minutes south of Alicante city and 90 minutes north of Murcia, Pilar de La Horadada occupies a sweet spot between accessibility and seclusion. The surrounding region is dotted with salt lakes, nature reserves, and the dramatic geology that makes this stretch of coast genuinely distinctive. For holiday home buyers, this means proximity to authentic experiences rather than commercialised attractions—you're buying into a place that feels like Spain, not a theme park version of it.
lifestyleSection: Living in Pilar de La Horadada as a holiday resident means embracing a slower rhythm without sacrificing modern conveniences. The established international community—primarily British, German, and Scandinavian—has created a welcoming ecosystem where English is widely spoken, yet Spanish culture permeates daily life. Your mornings might begin with fresh churros from the local baker, your afternoons at one of multiple Blue Flag beaches within 20 minutes, your evenings at family-run beach chiringuitos serving grilled fish and local wines. The weekly market offers farm-fresh produce, the supermarkets (Mercadona, Lidl, Consum) stock familiar brands alongside Spanish specialties, and healthcare access includes both public facilities and private English-speaking clinics within 30 minutes. Golf enthusiasts will appreciate several championship courses nearby. The expat community hosts social events, language exchanges, and activities without creating the artificial bubble that characterises some resort areas. You're never isolated, yet always able to find peaceful solitude. Internet connectivity supports remote work effortlessly. The car-friendly road network makes exploring the wider Costa Blanca seamless—from nature reserves to mountain villages to larger towns—while the slower pace of Torre De La Horadada itself encourages you to simply be.
investmentSection: Beyond its lifestyle appeal, this bungalow represents solid investment potential in a market trending upward. Pilar de La Horadada has experienced 8% year-on-year property value growth, outpacing broader Costa Blanca averages. At €4,936/m², this property commands a premium within the local market (where averages sit around €2,200/m²), reflecting its quality construction and strategic location. However, this premium represents exceptional value against Spanish island markets—the same specification would cost significantly more in Mallorca, Menorca, or Ibiza. Rental potential strengthens the investment case: holiday lets in this area typically achieve €800 per week (€3,400 monthly), meaning a property owner could recoup 10-12% annually through seasonal lettings while retaining personal use for premium weeks. The international demographic—affluent Europeans seeking reliable second homes—ensures consistent rental demand. Property taxes in Spain are modest, and recent reforms have made foreign investment increasingly straightforward. With growing interest in alternative Mediterranean destinations and increasing flight connectivity to Alicante, Torre De La Horadada is transitioning from hidden gem to recognised value destination.
conclusion: This exceptional 3-bedroom bungalow in Torre De La Horadada represents more than a property purchase—it's a gateway to the Mediterranean lifestyle you've imagined. At €385,000 with premium specification and 40% cost advantage over Spanish island markets, it combines lifestyle appeal with investment fundamentals. The established international community, pristine beaches within 20 minutes, year-round sunshine, and strong rental potential create a compelling ownership opportunity. Whether this becomes your cherished summer escape, a year-round retreat, or a reliable income-generating investment, the combination of authenticity, infrastructure, and value is genuinely rare. lifeAndAmenities.intro: Pilar de La Horadada offers all essential amenities with the authentic Spanish character that makes holiday living genuinely rewarding. From healthcare to shopping to transport, practical infrastructure supports comfortable living without the over-commercialisation of busier resorts.

healthcare.text: Healthcare in the region meets international standards with excellent English-language support. The nearest regional hospital, Hospital de Torrevieja, sits 28 minutes away and provides comprehensive emergency, surgical, and specialist services with English-speaking staff. Multiple private clinics operate throughout the area, offering faster appointment access and English-speaking doctors familiar with expat healthcare needs. Routine prescriptions are affordable, and dental and optical services are significantly cheaper than UK equivalents. The local health centre in Pilar de La Horadada provides basic GP services, and telemedicine consultations with UK doctors remain accessible for continuity of care. Travel insurance for holiday home owners is straightforward and affordable. Ambulance response times are quick, and helicopter emergency transport is available when needed.

education.text: The region supports several international schools following British, American, and other curricula—important for families with children or grandchildren visiting extended periods. International British School of Alicante (IBSA) operates 35 minutes away, offering full British GCSE and A-level provision with transport options. Numerous Spanish schools provide excellent education at modest cost, with many staff speaking English. Summer language programmes and enrichment activities are readily available. University options extend to nearby Alicante and Murcia, or maintained connections to UK universities remain straightforward for older students.

shopping.text: Shopping options range from major supermarket chains to authentic weekly markets. Mercadona, Lidl, and Consum provide familiar grocery shopping with Spanish specialties at excellent prices. The Thursday market in Pilar de La Horadada town centre offers farm-fresh produce, local crafts, and genuine social interaction—a highlight of many residents' weeks. Larger shopping centres in nearby Torrevieja (20 minutes) provide international brands, pharmacies, and restaurants. Online grocery delivery is increasingly available. Fresh fish comes directly from daily auctions at the small port, and local bakeries produce authentic pan tostado and speciality breads.

transport.text: Alicante International Airport (55 minutes) connects directly to UK, Europe, and beyond with reasonable flight costs. Bus connections link Pilar de La Horadada to surrounding towns, though a car is recommended for holiday home owners seeking flexibility. The road network is excellent—well-maintained motorways and local roads make exploring the wider region straightforward. Driving here is relaxed and foreign driving licences are accepted. Parking is abundant and typically free. Petrol costs are lower than UK equivalents. For those avoiding driving, local taxis are affordable and honest.

faqs.question: Combien coûte ce bien immobilier ?
faqs.answer: €385,000. This premium-specification 3-bedroom bungalow offers exceptional value compared to Spanish island markets (40% less expensive for equivalent quality). Payment options include cash, Spanish mortgages (available to foreigners), or flexible arrangements. The price includes all fixtures and fittings with ready-to-occupy condition.

faqs.question: La Costa Blanca est-elle un bon endroit pour acheter un bien immobilier ?
faqs.answer: Yes, absolutely. Costa Blanca combines authentic Mediterranean lifestyle, excellent year-round climate (300+ days sunshine), strong rental income potential, and steady property appreciation (8% annually in this area). It's particularly ideal for holiday home investors seeking reliable returns without the premium pricing of Spanish islands.

faqs.question: Les étrangers peuvent-ils acheter un bien immobilier en Espagne ?
faqs.answer: Yes, foreigners have the same property purchase rights as Spanish citizens. Non-residents can buy without residency permits or visas. You'll need a Spanish tax identification number (NIE), though this is straightforward to obtain. Many lawyers specialise in foreign buyer transactions and can guide the entire process seamlessly.

faqs.question: What are the typical costs of buying property in Spain?
faqs.answer: Beyond the purchase price (€385,000 here), expect: transfer tax (6-10% depending on region—typically 6% in Alicante), legal fees (€1,000-1,500), notary fees (€400-600), and property registration (€200-400). Total acquisition costs typically total 8-12% of purchase price. Les taxes foncières annuelles are modest (around 0.4-0.7% of property value).

faqs.question: Puis-je obtenir un prêt hypothécaire en Espagne en tant qu'étranger ?
faqs.answer: Yes, Spanish banks readily offer mortgages to foreign buyers. You'll typically need to provide income documentation, proof of funds, and undergo credit checks. Most lenders offer 70-80% loan-to-value ratios at competitive rates. Many British expats work with international mortgage brokers who specialise in Spanish financing and can secure better terms.

faqs.question: Quel est le coût de la vie sur la Costa Blanca ?
faqs.answer: Costa Blanca is notably affordable compared to UK and northern Europe. Grocery costs run 20-30% less than UK equivalents, restaurants offer excellent value (€10-15 three-course meals), and utilities are modest. Healthcare, property taxes, and services are all significantly cheaper. Holiday home owners typically spend €800-1,200 monthly on utilities, maintenance, and services.

faqs.question: Quel temps fait-il sur la Costa Blanca ?
faqs.answer: Exceptional. Over 300 days of annual sunshine, temperatures averaging 17°C in winter and 28°C in summer. Coastal breezes moderate summer heat, and rain is minimal (only 35-40 days annually). The Mediterranean microclimate creates ideal conditions for beach living year-round, making this perfect for holiday homes and seasonal living.

faqs.question: Is this property suitable for holiday lettings?
faqs.answer: Excellent potential. Similar properties in this area achieve €800 weekly rental rates (approximately €3,400 monthly). The 3-bedroom layout appeals to families and small groups. High demand from international tourists, particularly British and European visitors, ensures strong occupancy. Annual returns of 10-12% are realistic with professional management or personal letting during peak seasons.

faqs.question: À quelle distance se trouve la Costa Blanca de la France ?
faqs.answer: Alicante International Airport is 55 minutes away with direct flights to London, Manchester, Birmingham, and other UK cities. Flight times are typically 2-2.5 hours from London, and budget airline competition keeps costs reasonable. You can drive (ferries from southern Spain) but flying is the practical standard for holiday home owners.

faqs.question: What amenities are nearby in Torre De La Horadada?
faqs.answer: Tower De La Horadada offers excellent amenities within 5-30 minutes: Blue Flag beaches (18-22 minutes), supermarkets (5 minutes), weekly markets (5 minutes), golf courses (25-30 minutes), hospitals (28 minutes), international schools (35 minutes), and Alicante Airport (55 minutes). The town centre provides authentic restaurants, shops, and social spaces within walking distance of residential areas.
